update.description:
This is the code that creates an altitude sensor. On initialization the sensor marks its current altitude (position along the global Z axis) as the reference height. Then it reports the vertical displacement with respect to this reference point, as well as the vertical velocity.

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
update.title: Add altimeter sensor plus test

content.raw:
I think it would be nice to add more tests so we are sure the sensor works as expected in various situations. It would be nice to check some of the situations below, perhaps not all of them are necessary:

1. The model moves linearly and stops, and the sensor is updated accordingly. It would be nice to check for movement in Z and another direction or a combination. 

1. The model moves angularly and stops, and the sensor is updated accordingly. Same here about testing different combinations and combinations of angular + linear velocity. We can choose a few combinations which cover the most cases.

1. The model is moving with a linear velocity and the sensor gives the correct reading for position and velocity.

1. The model is moving with an angular velocity and the sensor gives the correct reading for position and velocity.
content.html:
I think it would be nice to add more tests so we are sure the sensor works as expected in various situations. It would be nice to check some of the situations below, perhaps not all of them are necessary:

  1. The model moves linearly and stops, and the sensor is updated accordingly. It would be nice to check for movement in Z and another direction or a combination.

  2. The model moves angularly and stops, and the sensor is updated accordingly. Same here about testing different combinations and combinations of angular + linear velocity. We can choose a few combinations which cover the most cases.

  3. The model is moving with a linear velocity and the sensor gives the correct reading for position and velocity.

  4. The model is moving with an angular velocity and the sensor gives the correct reading for position and velocity.

content.raw: If there's a relative pose between the sensor and the link, then the linear velocity of the sensor is different from the link's linear velocity, right? I think the link's angular velocity needs to be taken into account here.
content.html: If there's a relative pose between the sensor and the link, then the linear velocity of the sensor is different from the link's linear velocity, right? I think the link's angular velocity needs to be taken into account here.

content.raw: Could you document each field like [this](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/82b3f2539fe8027b36dc6b32b12ed586da2dd8c1/gazebo/msgs/log_playback_control.proto)?
content.html: Could you document each field like this?

update.description:
This is the code that creates an altitude sensor. On initialization the sensor marks its current altitude (position along the global Z axis) as the reference height. Then it reports the vertical displacement with respect to this reference point, as well as the vertical velocity.

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
update.title: Add altimeter sensor plus test
